item.title: ‘Star Search,’ Plus 7 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The finale of Netflix’s newest talent competition airs, and the second season of “The Last Thing He Told Me” premieres.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fidelman

item.title: In Xi Jinping’s Purge of the Military, a Search for Absolute Loyalty
item.description: By reaching back to Maoist tactics of “rectification,” the Chinese leader is signaling that control over the gun requires a state of perpetual cleansing.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo

media:content.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China at a ceremony with members of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army last year. Over the past two years, Mr. Xi has removed five of the six generals in China’s top military body.

item.title: Cortina’s 70-Year-Old Curling Stadium Is a Star at the Winter Olympics
item.description: It hosted Olympic hockey in 1956 and James Bond a quarter-century later. Cortina’s beloved Olympic Stadium is now bursting with excitement for curling.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight

media:content.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The roof of the at the Olympic Stadium in Cortina d’Ampezzo, which is hosting the 2026 Games with Milan.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Where’s My Olympic Medal? Right Here in the Sock Drawer.
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 16, 2026.

item.title: DNA Found on Gloves as Guthrie’s Daughter Makes New Plea
item.description: The F.B.I. said gloves found near Nancy Guthrie’s home carried a man’s DNA. The gloves appeared to match the ones seen in doorbell camera footage.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Sheriff’s deputies at a scene in Rio Rico, Ariz., during a search related to the disappearance of Nancy Guthrie.

item.title: ‘A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms’ Season 1, Episode 5 Recap: ‘Get Up!’
item.description: Duncan takes a serious beating. Egg doesn’t like how things are looking.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.category: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms (TV Program)

media:content.media:description: Egg (Dexter Sol Ansell) had good reason to look worried.

item.title: Diplomatic Feud With China Weighs on Japan’s Economy
item.description: A standoff over the security of Taiwan has led to a steep decline in the number of Chinese visitors to Japan, which is heavily dependent on the tourists.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis

media:content.media:description: A Chinese tour group in Tokyo last year. A decline in visitors has followed remarks by the Japanese prime minister suggesting Japan would come to Taiwan’s defense in the event of a Chinese invasion.

item.title: What to Know About the Homeland Security Shutdown
item.description: Funding for the Department of Homeland Security lapsed on Saturday amid a standoff over restrictions that Democrats have demanded for federal immigration agents. But much of its work continues.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Customs and Border Protection agents stopping vehicles in Minneapolis in January.

item.title: Kennedy Promises Action, Though Not Regulation, on Ultraprocessed Foods
item.description: The health secretary said the Food and Drug Administration would “act on” a request from a former F.D.A. commissioner to close a loophole on food safety.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and the Trump administration have so far been unwilling to use the F.D.A.’s regulatory authority to accomplish certain goals, including removing artificial dyes from foods.

item.title: 2025 Film Independent Spirit Awards: Complete Winners List
item.description: Here’s who went home with an Indie Spirit Award on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk

media:content.media:description: Eva Victor won the Best Screenplay award for her film “Sorry, Baby.”

item.title: Useful Camera Footage in Guthrie Case Proves Elusive
item.description: The lack of helpful video footage in Nancy Guthrie’s community may be hindered by several factors, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales

media:content.media:description: Nancy Guthrie with her youngest child, Savannah, a co-host of “Today,” NBC’s long-running morning show.

item.title: Warner Bros. Is Said to Consider Reopening Talks With Paramount
item.description: Warner Bros. Discovery had agreed to sell itself to Netflix, but its contract allows it to pursue offers that may lead to a superior deal.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch

media:content.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Warner Bros. Discovery has until Feb. 25 to respond to Paramount’s latest proposal.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 16, 2026
item.description: Ian Livengood gives us a sense of direction.
item.dc:creator: Tom Wright-Piersanti

media:content.media:credit: Bryan Steffy — Getty Images for Nightclub & Bar Media Group
media:content.media:description: Let’s noodle on today’s puzzle together, shall we?

item.title: Canada Gives U.S. Arms Makers the Cold Shoulder on Military Spending
item.description: Canada plans to unveil a new strategy that will shift its current reliance on American companies to Canadian military suppliers.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

media:content.media:credit: Spencer Colby/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney in Ottawa, Canada, on Wednesday.

item.title: Gisèle Pelicot Speaks
item.description: She was repeatedly drugged by her husband and raped in a series of crimes that shocked the world. Pelicot talked to us about her new memoir.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:credit: Philip Gay for The New York Times

item.title: Three American Speeches at Munich, and Plenty of Confusion
item.description: As the U.S. message veered from shared heritage and values to shared interests and back again, Europeans wondered what kind of alliance they were left with.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger

media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Sunday in Budapest, Hungary, where he traveled after addressing the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: Winter Storms Could Bring 8 Feet of Snow to Parts of California
item.description: The greatest impact is expected across Northern California, where a pair of powerful storms are expected to begin on Sunday night and last into the week.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar and Livia Albeck-Ripka

item.title: Jerry Kennedy, Who Helped Define Music in Nashville, Dies at 85
item.description: A guitarist and record producer, he played a role in creating hits by popular singers like Roger Miller, Roy Orbison, Tom T. Hall and Tammy Wynette.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.category: Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum

media:content.media:description: Jerry Kennedy in the 1970s posing at the Mercury Records studio control board in Nashville. “Jerry is truly one of the lead architects in the creation of the Nashville sound,” said Marty Stuart, a member of the Country Music Hall of Fame.

item.title: See the Looks From the 2026 Film Independent Spirit Awards
item.description: The awards show, which celebrates independent film and television, moved back to the Hollywood Palladium for this year’s awards show.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk

media:content.media:description: Rose Byrne, winner for Best Lead Performance for “If I Had Legs I’d Kick You.”

item.title: Pat Tillman’s Brother Pleads Guilty to Setting Post Office Fire
item.description: Richard Tillman, brother of the N.F.L. star turned Army Ranger who died in a case of friendly fire in Afghanistan, drove a vehicle into a California post office while it was closed.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: Richard Tillman at a ceremony in honor of his brother, Pat Tillman, in November 2004 in Arizona. He is standing next to his brother’s wife, Marie Tillman.

item.title: Kamala Harris vendió su lista de correos electrónicos y pagó deudas de 2024
item.description: El Partido Demócrata pagó 6,5 millones de dólares por la base de datos de los simpatizantes que aportaron para la campaña de Harris.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher

media:content.media:description: Kamala Harris recaudó 6,5 millones de dólares vendiendo su lista de correos electrónicos de millones de simpatizantes al Comité Nacional Demócrata.

item.title: Trump Administration Ends Credit for Start-Stop Feature in Cars
item.description: Manufacturers will no longer get a credit toward vehicle emissions standards by installing engines that automatically stop at red lights.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

media:content.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Complaints to the U.S. Department of Transportation about the start-stop feature peaked in 2022 and fell almost in half by 2024.

item.title: Like Trump, U.S. Embassies Are Raising Cash for Lavish July Fourth Parties
item.description: Some of Washington’s diplomatic outposts in Asia are raising millions for events to mark the 250th independence anniversary. One ambassador offered to sing and dance.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, River Akira Davis and Kenneth P. Vogel

media:content.media:description: The Washington Monument illuminated on New Year’s Eve. In December, President Trump announced a campaign to organize celebrations of America’s 250th birthday.

item.title: EE. UU. deporta a 9 migrantes en secreto, sin considerar sus protecciones legales
item.description: La mayoría tenían órdenes judiciales que los protegían de la expulsión a sus países de origen, por lo que fueron enviados a un centro de detención en Camerún.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:description: Una foto sin fecha del recinto donde están recluidos los deportados en Yaundé, capital de Camerún.

item.title: The Biggest Tricks From the Olympic Halfpipe, in Miniature
item.description: The halfpipe competitions in the 2026 Olympics again raised the bar for what’s possible on a snowboard. While the women faced difficult, snowy conditions, the medalists nonetheless put down impressive, clean runs. The men took their tricks to new heights and put together combinations never seen before.
item.dc:creator: Alice Fang, Jon Huang, Matt Ruby, Eden Weingart and Yuhan Liu

item.title: Light Snowfall Coming to New York, New Jersey and Long Island
item.description: Forecasters said snowfall totals of one to two inches were likely Sunday night, with isolated amounts of up to three inches across New York City, northeastern New Jersey and much of Long Island.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar and Johnny Diaz

media:content.media:description: In Woodside, Queens, where snow is still piled in the streets from earlier storms. Forecasters are predicting up to two more inches of snow, with isolated amounts of up to three inches, across New York City from Sunday into Monday.

item.title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Gallops Toward $82 Million in Global Ticket Sales
item.description: Warner Bros. spent an estimated $80 million on the R-rated romance, directed by Emerald Fennell, not including hefty marketing costs.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes

media:content.media:description: Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi in “Wuthering Heights.” The director, Emerald Fennell, and Ms. Robbie, a co-producer, went with Warner Bros. because it promised a wide theatrical release.

item.title: 5 conversaciones que debes tener con tus padres cuando envejecen
item.description: Muchas familias posponen estos temas. Pero hablar de ellos ahora puede conducir a un mejor cuidado en el futuro.
item.dc:creator: Simar Bajaj

item.title: A Speed Dating Event Where You Can Body-Slam Your Crush
item.description: At a wrestling speed dating event in Brooklyn, young people spent Valentine’s Day getting physical with strangers in hopes of finding love.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann

media:content.media:credit: Mila De La Torre for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Luiz Campos, top, and Tasneem Sarjoo tested their chemistry on the mat at a wrestling speed dating event on Saturday night.

item.title: In Munich, Lawmakers Concede Scars Remain After Trump’s Greenland Threat
item.description: Congress members said that President Trump’s coveting of Greenland had left a mark, even as they expressed hope for a less bellicose approach to foreign relations.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump’s statements on Greenland loomed large at Munich Security Conference, though top lawmakers said his threat to take the territory was “put to bed.”

item.title: Rosamund Pike in ‘Inter Alia’ and More Theater to Stream
item.description: Other picks include the National Theater’s “Inter Alia,” a successor to the acclaimed “Prima Facie”; Anne Gridley’s “Watch Me Walk”; and a Jodi Picoult stage adaptation.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Sherman

item.title: Bicepmaxxing at Calvin Klein
item.description: The muscles were more memorable than the clothes.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher

item.title: Europe Today Looks Different From the One Trump’s Team Describes
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio appealed to European leaders in Munich by stressing Christian and cultural bonds that are no longer universal.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley

media:content.media:description: Speaking over the weekend at the Munich Security Conference, Secretary of State Marco Rubio said, “We are part of one civilization: Western civilization.”

item.title: Three Olympic Athletes Were Just Disqualified for a Novel Reason: PFAS
item.description: Their skis and snowboards tested positive for “forever chemicals,” slippery-but-dangerous chemicals now banned in the Games.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi

media:content.media:description: Masaki Shiba of Japan was among the three disqualified. He said he knew of the ban and thought his equipment was in compliance.

item.title: Long Live Longevity Noodles
item.description: Grace Young’s classic recipe adds chicken and mushrooms to this must-have Lunar New Year dish.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Ko

media:content.media:credit: Romulo Yanes for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Vivian Lui.
media:content.media:description: Grace Young’s longevity noodles with chicken, ginger and mushrooms, adapted by Julia Moskin.

item.title: Trump’s Stinging Attack on Israel’s President Touches a Nerve
item.description: President Trump called President Isaac Herzog of Israel “disgraceful” because he has not yet pardoned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in his corruption trial.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner

media:content.media:description: President Trump with Israel’s president, Isaac Herzog, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at Ben Gurion Airport in October.

item.title: How Italy’s Federica Brignone Won Gold in Giant Slalom.
item.description: At 35, Federica Brignone of Italy became the oldest Olympic Alpine gold medalist. Mikaela Shiffrin of the U.S. finished a disappointing 11th.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and James Hill

media:content.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: How to Pay Attention
item.description: “Attention, taken to its highest degree, is the same thing as prayer,” the philosopher and mystic Simone Weil wrote.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson

media:content.media:credit: Jonathan Mehring for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: James Van Der Beek

item.title: In First Public Comments Since Trump’s Racist Video, Obama Laments Lost Decorum
item.description: In a podcast interview, former President Barack Obama did not directly address the video posted by Mr. Trump but denounced a “clown show” on social media.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Former President Barack Obama said he thought most Americans were troubled by inflammatory and racist rhetoric in politics.

item.title: How Feeding the Baby Can Affect Your Marriage
item.description: Readers discuss a guest essay asserting that formula promotes marriage equality. Also: Ethics and the Supreme Court.

item.title: What It Means to Hold Someone’s Attention With a Story
item.description: Learning about our family’s past can connect us to the turmoil and difference that have always been America’s story.
item.dc:creator: Roger Rosenblatt

item.title: Everybody’s Mom
item.description: We explore why we care so much about the disappearance of Nancy Guthrie.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley

media:content.media:description: News media and law enforcement personnel outside Nancy Guthrie’s home.

item.title: Could an Electronic Coach Help Ski Jumpers Leap Farther?
item.description: Future Olympic prospects are testing a device that can give them corrective advice in real time as they hurtle into the air.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler

item.title: Toward a Sane Christian Zionism
item.description: Toward a sane Christian Zionism.

item.title: The Olympics Take Themselves Too Seriously. Bring Back Ski Ballet.
item.description: You want at least one weird entree on the Olympics menu, even if only for the pleasure of not ordering it.
item.dc:creator: Bruce Handy

item.title: Ro Khanna Is Shaken by What He’s Learned From the Epstein Files
item.description: Epstein’s network may not have known everything, but it is hard to deny that many of them knew enough to know better.

item.title: Inside the 2026 Olympics
item.description: A look at the tensions and triumphs shaping this year’s Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Abrams, Motoko Rich, Shawna Richer, Juliet Macur, Luke Vander Ploeg, Tina Antolini, Alex Barron, Wendy Dorr, Rowan Niemisto, Daniel Powell, Leah Shaw Dameron, Diane Wong and Marion Lozano
